div1.p: Permit me to thank you for the copy of the The Century sent me, containing my story, "The March of ‸Progress". The story has a good place among excellent company, and the illustration is very effective. It is a pleasure to see, a specimen of one's work in your columns, & I hope it may not be the last.

Permit me to thank you also, on behalf of several readers,
for the poem by Paul L. Dunbar "The Haunted Oak," which appeared in the December Century. If trees could talk, the single oak could probably be only one of a large chorus.

person.note: Richard Watson Gilder was a poet and editor of the Century magazine. Нe worked as a reporter for the Newark Daily Advertiser and the Newark Morning Register before becoming editor of the magazine Hours At Home in 1869. When the latter was merged with the newly-founded Scribner's Monthly the following year, Gilder was made assistant editor under Josiah Gilbert Holland. Не succeeded Holland as editor-in-chief in 1881 and turned the publication, renamed The Century Illustrated Monthly Magazine, into the most renowned and influential general interest magazine in the United States ("Overview," Richard Watson Gilder papers, 1855-1916 Manuscripts and Archives Division, The New York Public Library, 1987: 1).

person.occupation: a poet, short story writer, dramatist, and lyricist
person.note: Paul Laurence Dunbar was one of the first important black poets in American literature and the first black American to achieve an international audience for his work. Best known for his poems in dialect, Dunbar became a sought-after writer at the turn of the century, popular with black and white audiences alike, and his work was featured in many newspapers and magazines. Critics received this work very well. The editor of Harper's Weekly gave the book an excellent review. A New York publishing company contracted with Dunbar to publish his two earlier collections as a single volume called Lyrics of a Lowly Life. It became an instant success ("Paul L. Dunbar," Ohio History Central, Ohio History Connection, 2020, https://ohiohistorycentral.org/w/Paul_L._Dunbar).

object.note: The Century Magazine was an American magazine published by The Century Company that replaced Scribner's Monthly Magazine in 1881. The magazine published illustrated articles on history, science, and literature, sometimes publishing fiction as well. In 1930, it merged with The Forum.

The short story "March of Progress" was published in The Century in 1901, and it features a dramaticization of the problem facing a black schoolboard in Patesville, North Carolina in the 1880s (William L. Andrews, The Literary Career of Charles W. Chesnutt, Louisiana State University Press, 1999: 82).

"The Haunted Oak," written and published in December 1900, in the Century was inspired in Washington, D.C., by a story that Dunbar heard an old black man telling of his nephew in Alabama who was hanged from an oak tree after having been falsely accused of "a grave crime." According to the story, shortly afterwards the leaves on the limb, used for the lynching, yellowed and fell off; and, unlike the rest of the normal tree, the offending bough shriveled and died. Townspeople began to call the tree "the haunted oak." Dunbar, using the ballad form to enhance the superstition, personifies the tree and makes it the most sensitive and remorseful participant in the crime (James A. Emanuel, "Racial Fire in the Poetry of Paul Laurence Dunbar," A Singer in the Dawn: Reinterpretations of Paul Laurence Dunbar, ed. Jay Martin, Dodd, Mead & Co., 1975: 81).
